sn11.7:4.2: “Once upon a time, mendicants, as Sakka, Lord of Gods, was in private solitude this thought came to his mind:
sn11.7:4.3: ‘I should never betray even a sworn enemy.’
sn11.7:4.4: And then Vepacitti, Lord of Demons, knowing what Sakka was thinking, approached him.
sn11.7:4.5: Sakka saw Vepacitti coming off in the distance,
sn11.7:5.1: ‘Dear sir, don’t give up the idea you just had!’
sn11.7:6.1: ‘Swear, Vepacitti, that you won’t betray me.’
sn11.7:7.1: ‘Whatever bad things happen to a liar,
sn11.7:7.2: or to someone who slanders the noble ones,
sn11.7:7.3: or to someone who betrays a friend,
sn11.7:7.6: anyone who betrays you, Sujā’s husband.’”
